root.publications: Marck, Jeffrey C. 1999. Revising Polynesian linguistic subgrouping and its culture history implications. In Roger Blench & Matthew Spriggs (eds.), Archaeolgy and Language IV: Language Change and Cultural Transformation, 95-122. London and New York: Routledge: Taylor & Francis Group.

child.pub-comments: “As there are no diagnostic arguments for Samoic-Outlier, I feel it must be abandoned in favour of the Samoan Ellicean-Eastern Polynesian group. East Futunan, East Uvean, Outliers other than Ellicean Outliers and Pukupuan therefore become unclassified Nuclear Polynesian languages” (Marck 1999:111).
child.geography: spoken in the Western Polynesian islands, see Figure 4.2
child.publications: Marck, Jeffrey C. 1999. Revising Polynesian linguistic subgrouping and its culture history implications. child.pub-comments: Node not named by author. “In Figure 4.1, Mangarevan is reclassified as diverging from Marquesan after Hawai'ian (Marck 1996)” (Marck 1999:98).
